posts.name: doruk bazan
posts.cooked: Hello, I'm Doruk from the 8557 mechanical department. We decided to do a small off-season project with my friend Batu from the electronics department. Our project involves converting the MK4 module into MK4i modules using parts we printed from a 3D printer. The main reason for this project is to resolve the issues we faced at customs. We aren't aiming to compete with third-party 3D printing parts; this is simply a recreational project.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: How does this develop? I'm curious about its progress.

posts.name: doruk bazan
posts.cooked: The text is: GOOD NEWS! Here is the photo of the finished printing of our parts; we will obtain the bearings from our local supplier to complete the assembly of the module, resulting in a few days of mandatory break.

posts.name: doruk bazan
posts.cooked: After a long break due to technical issues with our 3D printers, we have successfully assembled our module, which is functioning as planned. However, we also have another upcoming project. To achieve our goals, we aim to reduce the gear ratio and switch to a new module design that will increase its speed by 2-3 feet per second. This requires designing a module based on the materials we have and European standards, primarily to facilitate production. Keep an eye on our progress.

switch to a new module design that will increase its speed by 2-3 feet per second.

Really cool but looking at the pic it has neo 1.1 motors if that is what you plan on running on a competition weight robot trying to go faster than l3+(19ft/sec) which is the highest speed offered by SDS the acceleration is going to suffer. top speed is great if you have enough room to get up to speed but with shorter sprints acceleration with traction would be quicker

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.name: Göktürk Aytaç
posts.cooked: Are those wheels original or custom-made?

posts.name: doruk bazan
posts.cooked: Thank you for your feedback. As mentioned in our first post, this is a small off-season project. We plan to produce the module in metal, but due to torque-related losses, the speed of the metal-produced module will be closer to the SDS data. This ensures the robot remains durable and easy to move in the field, so we won’t alter the current torque levels when producing metal modules. Modules with modified torque are created solely through 3D printing, intended for educational and entertainment purposes for our rookie members.
